DESCRIPTION.P: This function may be used to get the characteristic numbers/properties of the floating point set denoted here by F(b,p,emin,emax) (usually the 64 bits float numbers set prescribe by IEEE 754). Numbers of F are of the form:
e is the exponent and m the mantissa:
d_i the digits are in [0, b-1] and e in [emin, emax], the number is said "normalised" if d_1 ~= 0. The following may be gotten:

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "radix"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is the radix b of the set F

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "digits"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is the number of digits p

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "huge"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is the max positive float of F

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "tiny"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is the min positive normalised float of F

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "denorm"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is a boolean (%t if denormalised numbers are used)

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "tiniest"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then if denorm = %t, pr is the min positive denormalised number else pr = tiny

DESCRIPTION_ITEM.label: prop = "eps"
DESCRIPTION_ITEM.SP: then pr is the epsilon machine ( generally (b^(1-p))/2 ) which is the relative max error between a real x (such than |x| in [tiny, huge]) and fl(x), its floating point approximation in F

SECTION.label: Remarks
SECTION.P: This function uses the lapack routine dlamch to get the machine parameters (the names (radix, digit, huge, etc...) are those recommended by the LIA 1 standard and are different from the corresponding lapack's ones) ; CAUTION: sometimes you can see the following definition for the epsilon machine : eps = b^(1-p) but in this function we use the traditionnal one (see prop = "eps" before) and so eps = (b^(1-p))/2 if normal rounding occurs and eps = b^(1-p) if not.
